**2023-24 Figure Skating Season**

The 2023-24 figure skating season is an ongoing season in the field of figure skating, which includes competitions and exhibitions in the disciplines of men's singles, women's singles, pairs skating, and ice dance.

**Season Notes**

The 2023-24 figure skating season began in June 2023 and is expected to conclude in April 2024. This season marks the 116th edition of the World Figure Skating Championships, which is scheduled to take place in March 2024.

### Age Eligibility

Skaters are eligible to compete in the 2023-24 figure skating season if they meet the age requirements set by the International Skating Union (ISU). For senior skaters, the age limit is 15 years old, while junior skaters must be at least 13 years old and no older than 19 years old.

**Changes**

Several changes have been made to the figure skating season, including updates to the partnership and coaching staff for various skaters.

### Partnership Changes

Several pairs skaters have undergone changes to their partnership during the 2023-24 season. Notable changes include:

* French pair skaters Vanessa James and Morgan Ciprès have parted ways, with James teaming up with Eric Gagnon.
* Russian pair skaters Evgenia Tarasova and Vladimir Morozov have ended their partnership, with Tarasova now skating with Mikhail Kuznetsov.

### Retirements

Several figure skaters have announced their retirement from competitive skating, including:

* American figure skater Nathan Chen has announced that he will retire from competitive skating after the 2023-24 season.
* Canadian figure skater Patrick Chan has also announced his retirement from competitive skating.

### Coaching Changes

Several coaches have undergone changes to their coaching staff during the 2023-24 season. Notable changes include:

* American figure skater Alysa Liu has parted ways with her coach, Lori Nichol, and is now training under the guidance of Becky Calhoun.
* Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva has ended her partnership with coach Eteri Tutberidze and is now training under the guidance of Konstantin Kostin.

### Nationality Changes

Several figure skaters have undergone changes to their nationality during the 2023-24 season. Notable changes include:

* Russian figure skater Alexandra Trusova has switched her nationality to be a citizen of the United States.
* Chinese figure skater Jin Boyang has switched his nationality to be a citizen of the United States.

**International Competitions**

Several international competitions have been cancelled or postponed due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and other reasons.

## Cancelled

Notable cancelled competitions include:

* The 2023 World Team Trophy has been cancelled due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
* The 2023 Challenge Cup has been postponed due to logistical issues.

**International Medalists**

Several figure skaters have won international medals during the 2023-24 season, including:

### Men's Singles

* Nathan Chen (USA) has won several international medals, including the gold medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.
* Shoma Uno (JPN) has won several international medals, including the silver medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.

### Women's Singles

* Alexandra Trusova (USA) has won several international medals, including the gold medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.
* Kamila Valieva (RUS) has won several international medals, including the silver medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.

### Pairs

* Evgenia Tarasova and Vladimir Morozov (RUS) have won several international medals, including the gold medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.
* Wenjing Sui and Cong Han (CHN) have won several international medals, including the silver medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.

### Ice Dance

* Madison Chock and Evan Bates (USA) have won several international medals, including the gold medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.
* Madison Hubbell and Zachary Donohue (USA) have won several international medals, including the silver medal at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.

**Records and Achievements**

Several figure skaters have set new records and achieved milestones during the 2023-24 season, including:

### Records

* Nathan Chen (USA) has set the record for the highest combined score in men's singles at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.
* Alexandra Trusova (USA) has set the record for the highest combined score in women's singles at the 2023 Grand Prix of Espoo.

### Achievements

* Nathan Chen (USA) has become the first skater to win three consecutive Grand Prix of Espoo titles in men's singles.
* Alexandra Trusova (USA) has become the first skater to win three consecutive Grand Prix of Espoo titles in women's singles.

**Season's Best Scores**

Several figure skaters have set new season's best scores during the 2023-24 season, including:

article:
The 2022 FIBA Under-17 Basketball World Cup was the 16th edition of the FIBA Under-17 Basketball World Cup, a basketball tournament for national teams of players who were born on or after January 1, 2005. The tournament was held in the United Arab Emirates from August 2 to August 14, 2022.

# Qualified teams

A total of 16 teams qualified for the tournament. The qualified teams were divided into four groups of four teams each.

| Group A | Group B | Group C | Group D |
|  Argentina |  Australia |  Canada |  France |
|  China |  Lithuania |  Russia |  Italy |
|  Germany |  New Zealand |  Nigeria |  Turkey |
|  United States |  Spain |  Ukraine |  Serbia |

# Venue

The tournament was held in Dubai and Sharjah, United Arab Emirates. The games were played at the following venues:

* Dubai Sports City Arena (Capacity: 8,000)
* Al-Awir Sports Hall (Capacity: 2,000)
* Al-Ahly Club Hall (Capacity: 2,000)
* Sharjah National Sport Hall (Capacity: 3,000)

# Draw

The draw for the tournament was held on July 8, 2022, in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

article:
**The Menu (2022 film)**

The Menu is a 2022 American psychological horror comedy film written and directed by Mark Mylod. The film stars Ralph Fiennes, Anya Taylor-Joy, Nicholas Hoult, and Hong Chau.

**Plot**

The Menu follows the story of Tyler (Nicholas Hoult), a young chef who is invited to a remote island by the reclusive and renowned chef Julian Slowik (Ralph Fiennes). Upon arrival, Tyler is introduced to a small group of guests who are also invited to dine at the island's exclusive restaurant, where Slowik serves a bespoke, multi-course meal. As the evening progresses, it becomes clear that the meal is not just a culinary experience, but a form of performance art that Slowik has designed to deliver a twisted and sinister message to his guests.

As the courses are served, the guests are forced to confront their own dark pasts and desires, and the lines between reality and performance begin to blur. The film builds towards a shocking climax as the guests realize the true nature of Slowik's intentions and the horrifying consequences of their participation in his twisted game.

**Cast**

* Ralph Fiennes as Julian Slowik
* Anya Taylor-Joy as Margot
* Nicholas Hoult as Tyler
* Hong Chau as Elsa
* Janet McTeer as Felicity
* John Leguizamo as George
* Reed Birney as Nancy
* Aimee Carrero as Danielle
* Mark St. Cyr as Tanya

**Production**

### Development

The Menu was first announced in 2020, with Mark Mylod set to direct and write the screenplay. The film was produced by Adam McKay, Betsy Koch, and Will Ferrell, among others. The project was reportedly greenlit with a budget of $15 million.

### Casting

The cast was assembled over several months, with Ralph Fiennes and Anya Taylor-Joy being the first to be announced. The film's director, Mark Mylod, has stated that he was drawn to the project's unique blend of horror and comedy, and that he wanted to create a film that would be both unsettling and entertaining.

### Filming

Principal photography for The Menu began in June 2021 and wrapped in August of the same year. The film was shot on location in New Zealand, with a small crew and a cast of experienced actors. Mylod has stated that he aimed to create a sense of realism and intimacy on set, using long takes and a minimalist approach to cinematography.

### Music

The Menu features a score by Colin Stetson, a Canadian musician and composer. Stetson's score is a key element of the film's atmosphere and tone, blending elements of horror and comedy to create a unique and unsettling sound. The film's soundtrack also features a selection of jazz and classical pieces, chosen to enhance the film's themes and mood.

**Release**

The Menu was released in the United States on November 18, 2022, in a limited theatrical run. The film was later released on streaming platforms on December 1, 2022. The film's release was met with generally positive reviews, with many critics praising its unique blend of horror and comedy.

**Reception**

### Box Office

The Menu performed moderately well at the box office, grossing $12.5 million in its opening weekend. The film's total worldwide gross was $24.5 million.

### Critical Response

The Menu received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising its unique blend of horror and comedy. The film holds a 73% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 6.5/10. On Metacritic, the film has a score of 62 out of 100, based on 34 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".

### Accolades

The Menu was nominated for several awards, including a Saturn Award for Best Horror Film and a Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Horror Movie. The film's cast, particularly Ralph Fiennes and Anya Taylor-Joy, received nominations for their performances.

**Notes**

The Menu has been praised for its unique blend of horror and comedy, as well as its thought-provoking themes and performances. However, some critics have noted that the film's pace and tone can be uneven, and that it may not be to every viewer's taste.

article:
**2022 Italian general election**

The 2022 Italian general election was held on 25 September 2022 to elect the members of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate of the Republic. The election was the 19th legislative election since the country's transition to democracy in 1948.

**Background**

The election was triggered by the collapse of the Italian government led by Mario Draghi in July 2022, which had been formed in a national unity government after the 2018 Italian general election. The Draghi government had struggled to maintain stability, particularly due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic crisis it triggered. In the months leading up to the election, various parties were engaged in intense negotiations to form a new government, but ultimately, no agreement was reached.

**Electoral campaign**

The electoral campaign for the 2022 Italian general election was one of the most complex and divisive in recent Italian history. The main parties competing in the election were:

* **Fratelli d'Italia (FdI)**: Led by Giorgia Meloni, FdI was a right-wing populist party that campaigned on a platform of law and order, national sovereignty, and a reduction in immigration.
* **Partito Democratico (PD)**: Led by Enrico Letta, PD was a center-left party that campaigned on a platform of social justice, environmental protection, and European integration.
* **Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)**: Led by Giuseppe Conte, M5S was a populist party that campaigned on a platform of anti-corruption, environmental protection, and direct democracy.
* **Forza Italia (FI)**: Led by Silvio Berlusconi, FI was a center-right party that campaigned on a platform of economic growth, tax cuts, and a reduction in public spending.

**Main parties' slogans**

During the campaign, the main parties used various slogans to attract voters. FdI's slogan was "Italia al centro" (Italy at the center), while PD's slogan was "Italia al lavoro" (Italy at work). M5S's slogan was "Vaffa la politica" (Screw politics), while FI's slogan was "Italia al futuro" (Italy to the future).

**Electoral debates**

The electoral debates were a significant part of the campaign, with the main parties engaging in several televised debates. The debates were moderated by journalists and focused on various topics, including the economy, immigration, and national security.

One of the most notable debates was the debate between Giorgia Meloni and Enrico Letta, which was broadcast on national television. During the debate, Meloni and Letta clashed on various issues, including immigration and national sovereignty.

**Electoral system**

The electoral system used in the 2022 Italian general election was a proportional representation system, with a threshold of 3% for parties to gain representation in the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate of the Republic. The system was designed to ensure that smaller parties had a voice in the parliament.

**Electoral lists**

The electoral lists for the 2022 Italian general election were as follows:

**Lists with parliamentary representation**

* **Fratelli d'Italia (FdI)**: 154 deputies and 41 senators
* **Partito Democratico (PD)**: 92 deputies and 28 senators
* **Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)**: 52 deputies and 17 senators
* **Forza Italia (FI)**: 45 deputies and 18 senators
* **Italia Viva (IV)**: 19 deputies and 6 senators
* **Azione (AZ)**: 18 deputies and 6 senators

**Lists without parliamentary representation**

* **Alleanza Verdi e Sinistra (AVS)**: 2.1% of the vote
* **Italia in Comune (IC)**: 1.3% of the vote
* **Democrazia Cristiana (DC)**: 1.2% of the vote
* **Unione Popolare (UP)**: 1.1% of the vote

**Lists running only in overseas constituencies**

* **Partito Repubblicano Italiano (PRI)**: 0.5% of the vote
* **Unione dei Democratici Cristiani e di Centro (UDC)**: 0.4% of the vote

**Opinion polls**

The opinion polls for the 2022 Italian general election showed a tight race between the main parties. According to a poll conducted by the Institute of Public Opinion, FdI was leading with 26.5% of the vote, followed by PD with 24.5% and M5S with 18.5%.

**Voter turnout**

The voter turnout for the 2022 Italian general election was 65.2%, with 23.9 million voters casting their ballots.

**Results**

**Chamber of Deputies**

* **Overall results**: FdI won 264 seats, PD won 218 seats, M5S won 120 seats, FI won 105 seats, IV won 52 seats, and AZ won 47 seats.
* **Proportional and FPTP results**: FdI won 154 seats in the proportional system and 110 seats in the FPTP system, PD won 92 seats in the proportional system and 126 seats in the FPTP system, M5S won 52 seats in the proportional system and 60 seats in the FPTP system, FI won 45 seats in the proportional system and 60 seats in the FPTP system.
* **Aosta Valley**: FdI won 1 seat, PD won 1 seat, M5S won 1 seat.
* **Overseas constituencies**: FdI won 3 seats, PD won 3 seats, M5S won 2 seats.

**Senate of the Republic**

* **Overall results**: FdI won 122 seats, PD won 90 seats, M5S won 41 seats, FI won 34 seats, IV won 17 seats, and AZ won 16 seats.
* **Proportional and FPTP results**: FdI won 41 seats in the proportional system and 81 seats in the FPTP system, PD won 28 seats in the proportional system and 62 seats in the FPTP system, M5S won 17 seats in the proportional system and 24 seats in the FPTP system, FI won 18 seats in the proportional system and 16 seats in the FPTP system.
* **Aosta Valley**: FdI won 1 seat, PD won 1 seat, M5S won 1 seat.
* **Trentino-Alto Adige**: FdI won 3 seats, PD won 3 seats, M5S won 2 seats.
* **Overseas constituencies**: FdI won 5 seats, PD won 5 seats, M5S won 3 seats.

**Leaders' races**

The leaders' races for the 2022 Italian general election were closely watched. Giorgia Meloni, the leader of FdI, won the most seats in the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate of the Republic.

**Electorate demographics**

The electorate for the 2022 Italian general election was diverse, with voters from various age groups, regions, and socio-economic backgrounds.

**Aftermath**

**Analysis**

The aftermath of the 2022 Italian general election was marked by a shift in the country's political landscape. FdI emerged as the largest party, with a significant majority in the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate of the Republic.

**Reactions**

**Politics**

The reaction from the political establishment was mixed. Some politicians welcomed the result, while others expressed concern about the implications of a FdI-led government.

**News press and others**

The news press and other media outlets provided extensive coverage of the election and its aftermath. Some outlets focused on the implications of a FdI-led government, while others highlighted the challenges facing the new government.

**Government formation**

The government formation process was complex, with various parties and groups engaging in negotiations to form a coalition government. Ultimately, FdI formed a coalition government with FI and IV, with Giorgia Meloni as Prime Minister.

The Masked Singer (American TV series) Season 9

The Masked Singer is a reality television singing competition series based on the South Korean program of the same name. The show features a group of contestants, known as "masks," who compete against each other by singing popular songs while wearing elaborate costumes and masks to conceal their identities.

# Panelists and host

The ninth season of The Masked Singer featured a panel of celebrity judges, including Nicole Scherzinger, Ken Jeong, and Niecy Nash. The show was hosted by Nick Cannon, who also hosted the previous eight seasons of the series.

# Production

The Masked Singer Season 9 was produced by Eureka Productions and Fox Alternative Entertainment, in association with 20th Television. The series was executive produced by Craig Plestis, and produced by Steve Altman and David Goldberg. The show was filmed in front of a live studio audience at the CBS Television City in Los Angeles, California.

# Contestants

The contestants for Season 9 of The Masked Singer were a diverse group of celebrities, including singers, actors, and athletes. The contestants competed in the show wearing elaborate masks and costumes, which were designed to conceal their identities.

article:
Minions: The Rise of Gru

Minions: The Rise of Gru is a 2022 animated comedy film directed by Kyle Balda and written by Matthew Fogel. The film is a spin-off of the Minions franchise and a prequel to the Despicable Me series. It follows the origin story of a young Gru, played by Steve Carell, as he forms the Vicious 6 and battles against his arch-nemesis, Wild Knuckles.

**Plot**

The film takes place in the 1970s and follows a young Gru, a 12-year-old boy with a wild dream to become a supervillain. Gru becomes obsessed with the Vicious 6, a group of six evil villains who have retired from their life of crime. He idolizes their leader, Wild Knuckles, and dreams of joining their ranks. However, the Vicious 6 is not interested in Gru, and instead, they recruit a new member, Nunie, who is a skilled fighter.

Gru is devastated and decides to form his own team of villains. He recruits a group of Minions, including Kevin, Stuart, Bob, and a few new recruits. Together, they plan to take down the Vicious 6 and prove themselves as better villains. Along the way, Gru learns valuable lessons about friendship, loyalty, and being true to oneself.

**Voice cast**

The film features a talented voice cast, including:

* Steve Carell as Gru
* Pierre Coffin as Kevin, Stuart, Bob, and the Minions
* Alan Arkin as Wild Knuckles
* Taraji P. Henson as Nunie
* Jean-Claude Van Damme as Jean-Clawed
* Lucy Lawless as Svengeance
* Dolph Lundgren as Jack-Grax
* Danny Trejo as Stronghold
* Russell Brand as King Gru
* Julie Andrews as Gru's Mother

**Production**

The film was produced by Illumination Entertainment and Universal Pictures. The story was written by Matthew Fogel, with Kyle Balda directing and Pierre Coffin co-directing. The animation was created by a team of over 500 artists, animators, and technicians. The film was produced in 3D and was filmed at Illumination's studio in Santa Monica, California.

**Music**

The film's soundtrack features a mix of original songs and popular tracks from the 1970s. The score was composed by Heitor Pereira, with additional music by Pharrell Williams and Ellie Goulding. The soundtrack was released on July 15, 2022, and features the hit single "Bad Guy" by Billie Eilish.

**Marketing and release**

The film was released in the United States on July 1, 2022, in 3D and IMAX formats. The film's marketing campaign included a series of trailers and TV spots, as well as a viral social media campaign that encouraged fans to share their own "Minion"-themed photos and videos.

The film's release was accompanied by a range of merchandise, including toys, clothing, and home decor items. The film's success at the box office was also fueled by its popularity among families and fans of the Minions franchise.

**Reception**

**Box Office**

Minions: The Rise of Gru was a major commercial success, grossing over $939 million worldwide. The film opened at number one at the box office, with a domestic gross of $122 million in its opening weekend. The film's success was driven by its popularity among families and fans of the Minions franchise.

**Critical response**

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising its humor, animation, and voice cast. The film holds a 77% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 6.5/10. The critical consensus on the site reads: "Minions: The Rise of Gru is a fun, if formulaic, addition to the Despicable Me franchise."

**Gentleminions TikTok trend**

The film's success on social media was fueled by the "Gentleminions" TikTok trend, which saw fans creating and sharing their own Minion-themed videos and photos. The trend became a global phenomenon, with millions of users participating and sharing their own content. The trend was fueled by the film's popularity and the release of a series of Minion-themed merchandise and promotions.

**Accolades**

Minions: The Rise of Gru was nominated for several awards, including:

* Annie Award for Best Animated Feature
* Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Animated Feature
* Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film

**Sequel**

Minions: The Rise of Gru was announced as the first in a new trilogy of Minions films, with a sequel and a third film set to be released in the coming years. The sequel is set to follow Gru as he becomes a supervillain and battles against a new arch-nemesis.

**Notes**

Minions: The Rise of Gru is the first film in the Minions franchise to be produced in 3D. The film's animation was created using a combination of computer-generated imagery and traditional animation techniques.

article:
**Neoplatonism**

Neoplatonism is a school of thought that emerged in the 3rd century AD, which integrated elements of Plato's philosophy with other Hellenistic and mystical influences. This philosophical movement had a profound impact on Western philosophy, influencing various fields including early Christianity, Gnosticism, and Islamic thought. Neoplatonism also played a significant role in shaping the intellectual landscape of the Byzantine Empire and the Western Renaissance.

**Origins of the term**

The term "Neoplatonism" was coined in the 19th century to distinguish this philosophical movement from the original teachings of Plato. The term "Neoplatonism" is derived from the Greek words "neos" (νέος), meaning "new," and "Platonism," referring to the philosophical school founded by Plato. This distinction acknowledges that Neoplatonism is not a direct continuation of Plato's thought but rather a distinct development that drew upon his ideas.

**Origins and history of classical Neoplatonism**

### Hellenism

Neoplatonism emerged in the 3rd century AD, a period marked by the decline of the Roman Empire and the rise of Hellenism. Hellenism, also known as the Hellenistic period, was characterized by the spread of Greek culture, philosophy, and science throughout the Mediterranean world. This cultural exchange laid the groundwork for the development of Neoplatonism, which synthesized Greek philosophy with other Hellenistic influences.

### Ammonius Saccas

Ammonius Saccas (c. 175-242 AD) is often considered the founder of Neoplatonism. Although little is known about his life, his teachings are believed to have been a significant influence on the development of the school. Ammonius was a philosopher and mystic who drew upon various sources, including Plato, Plotinus, and the mysteries of Egypt. His teachings emphasized the importance of spiritual practices and the attainment of gnosis, or spiritual knowledge.

### Plotinus

Plotinus (c. 205-270 AD) is the most famous and influential Neoplatonist philosopher. Born in Lycopolis, Egypt, Plotinus traveled to Rome, where he studied philosophy under the tutelage of Ammonius. He later founded a philosophical school in Rome, which attracted many students, including Porphyry. Plotinus' teachings focused on the nature of reality, the soul, and the ultimate goal of human existence. His philosophy emphasized the importance of spiritual practices and the attainment of gnosis.

### Porphyry

Porphyry (c. 234-305 AD) was a student of Plotinus and a prominent Neoplatonist philosopher in his own right. He is best known for his work "Isagoge," a comprehensive introduction to Neoplatonist philosophy. Porphyry's teachings built upon Plotinus' ideas, emphasizing the importance of logic and reason in understanding the nature of reality. He also developed a system of categorization and classification, which had a lasting impact on Western philosophy.

### Iamblichus

Iamblichus (c. 245-325 AD) was a Neoplatonist philosopher who flourished in the 3rd century AD. A student of Porphyry, Iamblichus developed a unique system of philosophy that emphasized the importance of ritual and magical practices. His teachings drew upon various sources, including Plato, Plotinus, and the mysteries of Egypt. Iamblichus' philosophy focused on the attainment of gnosis and the attainment of spiritual knowledge.

### Academies

The Neoplatonist academies were schools of philosophy that flourished in the 3rd to 6th centuries AD. These academies were founded by prominent Neoplatonist philosophers, including Plotinus and Proclus. The academies served as centers of learning, where students could study philosophy, mathematics, and other subjects. The Neoplatonist academies played a significant role in shaping the intellectual landscape of the Byzantine Empire.

### Hypatia

Hypatia (c. 350-415 AD) was a Neoplatonist philosopher and mathematician who lived in Alexandria. A prominent teacher and scholar, Hypatia was known for her advanced knowledge of mathematics and philosophy. Her teachings emphasized the importance of reason and critical thinking. Hypatia's life and teachings had a lasting impact on Western philosophy, influencing the development of medieval Christian thought.

### Proclus

Proclus (c. 412-485 AD) was a Neoplatonist philosopher who flourished in the 5th century AD. A student of Syrianus, Proclus developed a unique system of philosophy that emphasized the importance of reason and logic. His teachings drew upon various sources, including Plato, Plotinus, and the mysteries of Egypt. Proclus' philosophy focused on the attainment of gnosis and the attainment of spiritual knowledge.

**Ideas**

### The One

The concept of the One is central to Neoplatonist philosophy. The One refers to the ultimate reality, the source of all being and existence. The One is often described as a unity, a singularity that underlies all of existence. This concept is rooted in Plato's idea of the Form of the Good, which is the ultimate source of all being and knowledge.

### Emanations

Neoplatonist philosophy emphasizes the idea of emanations, which refers to the process by which the One generates the universe. According to this concept, the One emanates a series of divine beings, each of which is a reflection of the One. These divine beings are often referred to as the nous, the world-soul, and the phenomenal world.

### Demiurge or nous

The concept of the Demiurge or nous is central to Neoplatonist philosophy. The Demiurge refers to the divine being who creates and governs the universe. The nous is often described as the divine mind or intellect, which is the source of all knowledge and wisdom.

### World-soul

The world-soul is a concept that refers to the divine being that animates the universe. According to Neoplatonist philosophy, the world-soul is a manifestation of the One, and is responsible for the organization and governance of the universe.

### Phenomenal world

The phenomenal world refers to the physical world that we experience through our senses. According to Neoplatonist philosophy, the phenomenal world is a manifestation of the divine, and is subject to the laws and principles of the One.

### Celestial hierarchy

The celestial hierarchy is a concept that refers to the hierarchical structure of the universe. According to Neoplatonist philosophy, the universe is organized into a series of levels or realms, each of which is governed by a divine being.

### Evil

The concept of evil is central to Neoplatonist philosophy. According to this concept, evil is a manifestation of the absence of being, and is therefore a privation of the divine. Evil is often seen as a corruption or distortion of the good, rather than a positive entity in its own right.

### Return to the One

The concept of the return to the One is central to Neoplatonist philosophy. According to this concept, the ultimate goal of human existence is to return to the One, to attain gnosis and to become one with the divine.

**Influence**

### Early Christianity

Neoplatonism had a significant influence on early Christianity. Many early Christian thinkers, including Augustine and Origen, drew upon Neoplatonist ideas in their writings. Neoplatonism's emphasis on the importance of reason and critical thinking also influenced the development of Christian theology.

### Augustine

Augustine (c. 354-430 AD) was a Christian thinker who was heavily influenced by Neoplatonism. His writings often drew upon Neoplatonist ideas, particularly in his discussion of the nature of God and the human soul.

### Origen and Pseudo-Dionysius

Origen (c. 185-254 AD) and Pseudo-Dionysius (c. 500 AD) were Christian thinkers who were heavily influenced by Neoplatonism. Their writings often drew upon Neoplatonist ideas, particularly in their discussion of the nature of God and the human soul.

### Gnosticism

Neoplatonism also influenced the development of Gnosticism, a philosophical and religious movement that emphasized the importance of spiritual knowledge and the attainment of gnosis. Gnostic thinkers often drew upon Neoplatonist ideas, particularly in their discussion of the nature of the divine and the human soul.

### Byzantine education

Neoplatonism played a significant role in shaping the intellectual landscape of the Byzantine Empire. The Neoplatonist academies were centers of learning, where students could study philosophy, mathematics, and other subjects. The Neoplatonist emphasis on reason and critical thinking also influenced the development of Byzantine education.

### Islamic neoplatonism

Neoplatonism also influenced the development of Islamic thought. Many Islamic thinkers, including Ghazali and Ibn Sina, drew upon Neoplatonist ideas in their writings. The Neoplatonist emphasis on the importance of reason and critical thinking also influenced the development of Islamic philosophy.

### Jewish thought

Neoplatonism also influenced the development of Jewish thought. Many Jewish thinkers, including Maimonides and Halevi, drew upon Neoplatonist ideas in their writings. The Neoplatonist emphasis on the importance of reason and critical thinking also influenced the development of Jewish philosophy.

### Medieval Christian Thought

Neoplatonism continued to influence medieval Christian thought. Many medieval Christian thinkers, including Thomas Aquinas and Duns Scotus, drew upon Neoplatonist ideas in their writings. The Neoplatonist emphasis on the importance of reason and critical thinking also influenced the development of medieval Christian theology.

### Western Renaissance

Neoplatonism also influenced the Western Renaissance. Many Renaissance thinkers, including Marsilio Ficino and Pico della Mirandola, drew upon Neoplatonist ideas in their writings. The Neoplatonist emphasis on the importance of reason and critical thinking also influenced the development of Renaissance humanism.

### Cambridge Platonists (17th century)

The Cambridge Platonists were a group of thinkers who sought to revive Neoplatonism in the 17th century. They emphasized the importance of reason and critical thinking, and drew upon Neoplatonist ideas in their writings.

### Modern neoplatonism

Modern neoplatonism is a movement that seeks to revive Neoplatonism in the modern era. It emphasizes the importance of reason and critical thinking, and draws upon Neoplatonist ideas in its writings. Modern neoplatonism is often seen as a response to the limitations of modern science and technology.

* Neoplatonism was influenced by a wide range of sources, including Plato, Aristotle, and the Stoics.

**2022 ATP Tour**

The 2022 ATP Tour was the global elite men's professional tennis circuit organized by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) for the 2022 tennis season. The ATP Tour is the highest level of professional tennis tournaments, and it is the most prestigious tennis circuit in the world.

**Schedule**

The 2022 ATP Tour calendar consisted of 67 tournaments, including the four Grand Slam tournaments, 38 ATP Masters 1000 events, 12 ATP 500 events, and 13 ATP 250 events. The tour began on January 3, 2022, and concluded on November 6, 2022.

### January

The first month of the 2022 ATP Tour saw the start of the season with the ATP Cup, a team competition featuring 12 countries. The tournament was held in Sydney, Australia, from January 1 to 9, 2022. The ATP 250 tournament in Adelaide, Australia, was also held in January, featuring top players like Novak Djokovic and Daniil Medvedev.

### February

February saw the start of the hard court season with the ATP 500 tournament in Delray Beach, Florida, and the ATP 250 tournament in New York City. The tournament in Delray Beach was won by Hubert Hurkacz, while the tournament in New York City was won by Jannik Sinner.

### March

In March, the ATP Tour shifted to the clay court season, with the ATP 1000 tournament in Indian Wells, California. The tournament was won by Rafael Nadal, who defeated Daniil Medvedev in the final. The ATP 250 tournament in Barcelona, Spain, was also held in March, featuring top players like Nadal and Dominic Thiem.

### April

April saw the start of the clay court season in Europe, with the ATP 1000 tournament in Monte-Carlo, Monaco. The tournament was won by Stefanos Tsitsipas, who defeated Alejandro Davidovich Fokina in the final. The ATP 500 tournament in Hamburg, Germany, was also held in April, featuring top players like Nadal and Matteo Berrettini.

### May

In May, the ATP Tour shifted to the grass court season, with the ATP 250 tournament in Geneva, Switzerland, and the ATP 500 tournament in Lyon, France. The tournament in Geneva was won by Casper Ruud, while the tournament in Lyon was won by Cameron Norrie.

### June

June saw the start of the grass court season in the UK, with the ATP 250 tournament in Stuttgart, Germany, and the ATP 500 tournament in Halle, Germany. The tournament in Stuttgart was won by Hubert Hurkacz, while the tournament in Halle was won by Roger Federer.

### July

In July, the ATP Tour shifted to the hard court season, with the ATP 500 tournament in Hamburg, Germany, and the ATP 250 tournament in Newport, Rhode Island. The tournament in Hamburg was won by Lorenzo Musetti, while the tournament in Newport was won by John Isner.

### August

August saw the start of the US Open series, with the ATP 250 tournament in Washington, D.C., and the ATP 500 tournament in Winston-Salem, North Carolina. The tournament in Washington, D.C. was won by Nick Kyrgios, while the tournament in Winston-Salem was won by Ilya Ivashka.

### September

In September, the ATP Tour shifted to the hard court season in Asia, with the ATP 500 tournament in Beijing, China, and the ATP 250 tournament in Zhuhai, China. The tournament in Beijing was won by Jiří Veselý, while the tournament in Zhuhai was won by Jannik Sinner.

### October

October saw the start of the European indoor season, with the ATP 1000 tournament in Paris, France. The tournament was won by Novak Djokovic, who defeated Denis Shapovalov in the final. The ATP 250 tournament in Antwerp, Belgium, was also held in October, featuring top players like Alexander Zverev and Stefanos Tsitsipas.

### November

In November, the ATP Tour concluded with the ATP 500 tournament in Sofia, Bulgaria, and the ATP 250 tournament in Bazel, Switzerland. The tournament in Sofia was won by Daniil Medvedev, while the tournament in Bazel was won by Casper Ruud.

**Affected tournaments**

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, several tournaments were affected in 2022. The ATP 250 tournament in Melbourne, Australia, was cancelled, while the ATP 500 tournament in Madrid, Spain, was postponed to October. The ATP 1000 tournament in Rome, Italy, was also postponed to September.

article:
**The Bad Guys**

**Introduction**

The Bad Guys is a 2022 American computer-animated comedy film produced by DreamWorks Animation. The film is based on the 2016 children's novel of the same name by Aaron Blabey. The story follows a group of animals who are considered "bad guys" by society, but ultimately show that they have good hearts. The film features an all-star voice cast, including Sam Rockwell, Awkwafina, Anthony Ramos, and Marc Maron. The Bad Guys has received widespread critical acclaim for its witty dialogue, engaging storyline, and impressive animation.

**Plot**

The Bad Guys follows the story of a group of animals who are considered "bad guys" by society. They include a wolf, a snake, a ferret, and a polar bear, all of whom are convicted of various crimes and are serving time in a maximum-security prison. However, they soon discover that they have more in common than they initially thought, and they begin to form a bond with each other.

The group is led by Mr. Wolf (voiced by Sam Rockwell), a charismatic and cunning leader who has a soft spot for his fellow inmates. Along with his loyal sidekick, Mr. Snake (voiced by Awkwafina), they hatch a plan to escape from prison and start a new life on the outside.

However, their plan is soon complicated by the arrival of a new prisoner, Diane Foxington (voiced by Zazie Beetz), a tough and sassy raccoon who has a hidden past. As the group navigates the complexities of their new life outside of prison, they must also confront their own personal demons and learn to work together in order to succeed.

**Voice cast**

The voice cast for The Bad Guys includes:

* Sam Rockwell as Mr. Wolf
* Awkwafina as Ms. Snake

* Marc Maron as Professor Hawk
* Zazie Beetz as Diane Foxington
* Craig Robinson as Sharkey
* Alex Borstein as Leopold
* Lil Rel Howery as Tarantula
* Richard Ayoade as Norbert

**Production**

### Development

The idea for The Bad Guys was first conceived by Aaron Blabey, who wrote the original novel. Blabey was inspired by his own experiences as a child, growing up in a family of animal lovers. He wanted to create a story that would explore the complexities of animal behavior and challenge the common perception of "good" and "bad" animals.

### Animation, design, and influences

The animation for The Bad Guys was created by DreamWorks Animation, using a combination of computer-generated imagery (CGI) and traditional animation techniques. The film's design team was inspired by a range of sources, including classic cartoons, anime, and even comic books. The team also drew inspiration from real-world animals, studying their behavior and anatomy in order to create more realistic and believable characters.

**Music**

The music for The Bad Guys was composed by Mychael Danna, who has worked on a range of animated films and television shows. The soundtrack features a range of catchy and upbeat tracks, from the opening credits sequence to the closing credits. The music is a key element of the film's tone and style, adding to the sense of energy and excitement.

**Marketing**

The film's trailer was released in June 2022, showcasing the film's action-packed and humorous tone. The trailer was a huge hit, generating widespread buzz and excitement among fans and critics alike.

**Release**

### Theatrical

The Bad Guys was released in theaters on March 17, 2022, in a range of countries around the world. The film was a commercial success, grossing over $60 million on its opening weekend. The film's success was largely due to its positive word-of-mouth, with audiences praising the film's humor, animation, and heart.

### Home media and streaming

The Bad Guys was released on home media and streaming platforms on June 7, 2022. The film was available on a range of platforms, including DVD, Blu-ray, and digital streaming services. The film's home media release was a huge success, with many fans and critics praising the film's bonus features and behind-the-scenes content.

**Reception**

### Box office

### Critical response

The Bad Guys received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the film's witty dialogue, engaging storyline, and impressive animation. The film holds a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising the film's humor and heart.

### Accolades

article:
**Opera in Ukraine**

Ukrainian opera is a rich and diverse art form that has a long and complex history. From its origins in the 19th century to the present day, Ukrainian opera has evolved and flourished, reflecting the country's cultural, social, and political developments.

**Origins**

The origins of Ukrainian opera can be traced back to the 19th century, when the concept of national revival was growing in Ukraine. During this period, Ukrainian intellectuals and artists sought to create a distinct Ukrainian identity, separate from Russian and Polish influences.

### Shkilʹna dramy (school dramas)

One of the earliest forms of Ukrainian drama was the shkilʹna dramy (school drama), which emerged in the 1830s. These plays were written by Ukrainian educators and intellectuals, who aimed to create a sense of national pride and identity among the Ukrainian people. Shkilʹna dramy was a key factor in the development of Ukrainian language and literature, as it helped to standardize the Ukrainian language and create a sense of national unity.

### Vertepy (nativity scenes)

Vertepy, or nativity scenes, were another important form of Ukrainian drama that emerged in the 19th century. These scenes were often performed during Christmas and Easter, and told the story of the life of Jesus Christ. Vertepy was a key factor in the development of Ukrainian folk theater, as it helped to create a sense of community and shared identity among the Ukrainian people.

### Vaudeville

Vaudeville, a form of popular entertainment that emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, also played an important role in the development of Ukrainian opera. Vaudeville shows often featured music, dance, and comedy, and were popular among the Ukrainian people. Ukrainian vaudeville shows often featured Ukrainian music and dance, and helped to promote Ukrainian culture and identity.

**Operetta**

Operetta, a form of musical theater that emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, also played an important role in the development of Ukrainian opera. Operetta shows often featured music, dance, and comedy, and were popular among the Ukrainian people. Ukrainian operetta shows often featured Ukrainian music and dance, and helped to promote Ukrainian culture and identity.

**Obstacles to the development of Ukrainian-language opera**

Despite the growth of Ukrainian culture and identity, there were many obstacles to the development of Ukrainian-language opera. The Russian Empire, which ruled Ukraine from the 18th to the 20th centuries, suppressed Ukrainian language and culture, and often forced Ukrainian artists to perform in Russian. This made it difficult for Ukrainian artists to express themselves in their own language and culture.

**Emergence of Ukrainian opera**

Despite these obstacles, Ukrainian opera began to emerge in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. One of the key figures in the development of Ukrainian opera was Mykola Lysenko.

### Mykola Lysenko

Mykola Lysenko was a Ukrainian composer and pianist who is often considered the father of Ukrainian opera. Lysenko was born in 1842 and studied music in Kiev and St. Petersburg. He began to compose music in the 1860s, and his early works were influenced by Russian and European music. However, as Lysenko became more interested in Ukrainian culture and identity, his music began to take on a more Ukrainian character. Lysenko's operas often featured folk melodies and themes, and were based on Ukrainian history and mythology.

### Lysenko's contemporaries and successors

Lysenko was not alone in his efforts to create Ukrainian opera. Many other composers and artists were working in Ukraine during this period, and they often collaborated with Lysenko on his operas. Some of Lysenko's contemporaries and successors include:

* Panas Saksahansky, a Ukrainian composer and pianist who was a close friend and collaborator of Lysenko's
* Mykola Lysenko's son, Levko Lysenko, who was a composer and conductor who continued his father's work
* Sergei Lyapunov, a Russian composer who was influenced by Lysenko's music and often incorporated Ukrainian themes and melodies into his own works

**Period of resurgence**

In the 1910s and 1920s, Ukrainian opera experienced a period of resurgence. This was due in part to the rise of Ukrainian independence movements, which sought to create a separate Ukrainian state. Ukrainian opera was seen as a key part of this movement, and many composers and artists began to create works that reflected Ukrainian culture and identity.

### 1910s

In the 1910s, Ukrainian opera began to take on a more modern character. Composers such as Lysenko and Saksahansky began to experiment with new forms and styles, and the use of Ukrainian folk music and themes became more widespread.

### 1920s and early 1930s

In the 1920s and early 1930s, Ukrainian opera experienced a period of rapid growth and development. The Soviet government, which had come to power in Ukraine in 1920, encouraged the development of Ukrainian culture and identity. Ukrainian opera became a key part of this movement, and many composers and artists began to create works that reflected Ukrainian history and mythology.

#### Historical opera

One of the key trends in Ukrainian opera during this period was the creation of historical operas. These operas often told the story of Ukraine's past, and featured Ukrainian heroes and heroines. Some examples of historical operas from this period include:

* "Taras Bulba" by Mykola Lysenko, which tells the story of a Ukrainian Cossack leader
* "Ivan Pidkova" by Mykola Lysenko, which tells the story of a Ukrainian revolutionary leader
* "The Cossack Beyond the Danube" by Mykola Lysenko, which tells the story of a Ukrainian Cossack leader who fights against the Ottoman Empire

**Stalinism (1932–1956)**

In 1932, the Soviet government began to implement a policy of Stalinism in Ukraine. This policy was characterized by a suppression of Ukrainian culture and identity, and a promotion of Russian culture and values. Ukrainian opera was heavily affected by this policy, as many Ukrainian composers and artists were forced to conform to Soviet standards.

#### World War II

During World War II, Ukraine was invaded by Germany and occupied for several years. Ukrainian opera continued to exist during this period, but it was heavily influenced by the occupation. Many Ukrainian composers and artists were forced to create works that were acceptable to the German authorities, and Ukrainian opera became a way for Ukrainians to express their resistance to the occupation.

#### 1945–1953

After the war, Ukrainian opera experienced a period of repression under the Soviet government. Many Ukrainian composers and artists were forced to conform to Soviet standards, and Ukrainian opera became a way for Ukrainians to express their national identity in a way that was acceptable to the Soviet authorities.

**1953–1991**

In 1953, Nikita Khrushchev came to power in the Soviet Union and began to implement a policy of de-Stalinization. This policy allowed for the expression of Ukrainian culture and identity, and Ukrainian opera began to flourish once again.

#### 1953–1970

During the 1950s and 1960s, Ukrainian opera experienced a period of rapid growth and development. Many new operas were written, and the use of Ukrainian folk music and themes became more widespread.

#### 1970s

In the 1970s, Ukrainian opera began to take on a more modern character. Composers such as Mykola Lysenko and Panas Saksahansky continued to experiment with new forms and styles, and the use of electronic music and multimedia became more widespread.

#### 1980s

In the 1980s, Ukrainian opera experienced a period of rapid growth and development. The Soviet government, which had come to power in Ukraine in 1920, began to relax its control over Ukrainian culture and identity. Ukrainian opera became a key part of this movement, and many composers and artists began to create works that reflected Ukrainian history and mythology.

**Post-independence operas**

In 1991, Ukraine gained independence from the Soviet Union, and Ukrainian opera was able to flourish once again. Many new operas were written, and the use of Ukrainian folk music and themes became more widespread.

**Opera houses**

Ukraine has a number of opera houses, including:

* The Kyiv Opera House, which is one of the oldest and most prestigious opera houses in Ukraine
* The Lviv Opera House, which is known for its beautiful architecture and historic significance
* The Odessa Opera House, which is one of the oldest and most respected opera houses in Ukraine

article:
**Twitter Files**

The Twitter Files is a series of internal documents and communications released by Elon Musk, the owner of Twitter, that shed light on the social media platform's content moderation policies, relationships with government agencies, and interactions with influential users.

**Background**

Twitter was founded in 2006 and has since become one of the largest social media platforms in the world, with over 440 million monthly active users. The platform has faced numerous challenges in balancing free speech with content moderation, particularly in the wake of the 2020 United States presidential election and the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Topics**

### **No. 1: Content moderation of New York Post story**

In October 2020, the New York Post published a story about Hunter Biden, the son of then-presidential candidate Joe Biden, that included unverified allegations about his business dealings. Twitter faced criticism for initially limiting the story's visibility on the platform, citing concerns about the article's credibility. The decision sparked a debate about the role of social media companies in content moderation and the limits of their editorial discretion.

Twitter eventually reversed its decision and allowed the story to be shared on the platform, but not before it had already been widely shared and reported on by other news outlets. The episode highlighted the challenges faced by social media companies in balancing their responsibilities as intermediaries and their obligations to protect their users from misinformation.

### **No. 2: Visibility filtering**

Twitter has a feature called "visibility filtering" that allows users to choose which types of content they want to see on their timelines. The feature uses algorithms to determine which tweets are relevant and interesting to each user, and which ones to hide or downrank. Critics have argued that this feature can be used to suppress certain types of content or viewpoints, particularly those that are unpopular or offensive.

In 2020, Twitter introduced a new feature called "display filtering" that allowed users to choose which types of content they wanted to see on their timelines, including tweets from specific accounts or hashtags. The feature was designed to help users tailor their experience on the platform, but it also raised concerns about the potential for censorship and the limits of user choice.

### **Nos. 3–5: Attack on the Capitol and suspension of Donald Trump**

In January 2021, a mob of supporters of then-President Donald Trump stormed the United States Capitol in an attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. Twitter suspended Trump's account for 12 hours after the incident, citing concerns about the spread of misinformation and the potential for violence.

The decision sparked a debate about the limits of free speech on social media and the responsibilities of social media companies in policing their platforms. Some argued that Twitter had overstepped its bounds by suspending Trump's account, while others argued that it had failed to take adequate action to prevent the spread of misinformation.

### **Nos. 6–7: FBI communications with Twitter Trust and Safety Team**

In 2020, it was reported that the FBI had been in contact with Twitter's Trust and Safety team in the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election. The communications were reportedly focused on concerns about election interference and the spread of misinformation.

The revelation sparked a debate about the role of law enforcement in social media content moderation and the potential for government overreach. Some argued that the FBI's communications with Twitter were necessary to prevent election interference, while others argued that they represented a threat to free speech and the independence of social media companies.

### **Nos. 8–9: Relationship with the U.S. government**

Twitter has a complex relationship with the U.S. government, which has been shaped by a series of high-profile controversies and disputes. In 2018, Twitter was subpoenaed by the House Intelligence Committee as part of its investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

The subpoena sparked a debate about the limits of government authority over social media companies and the potential for overreach. Some argued that Twitter had a responsibility to cooperate with government requests, while others argued that it had a duty to protect its users' free speech rights.

### **No. 10: Moderation of COVID-19 content**

In 2020, Twitter faced criticism for its handling of COVID-19 content on the platform. Some argued that the company had been too lax in its moderation of misinformation about the virus, while others argued that it had been too aggressive in its enforcement of its policies.

The controversy highlighted the challenges faced by social media companies in balancing their responsibilities as intermediaries and their obligations to protect their users from misinformation. Twitter eventually introduced a series of measures aimed at improving its moderation of COVID-19 content, including the use of fact-checking labels and the removal of accounts that spread misinformation.

### **No. 15: Hamilton 68 Dashboard**

In 2018, it was reported that Twitter had been working with the Alliance for Securing Democracy, a group founded by the German Marshall Fund of the United States, to develop a dashboard called the Hamilton 68. The dashboard was designed to track and analyze the spread of Russian propaganda on Twitter, but it was widely criticized for its methodology and its potential for bias.

The controversy highlighted the challenges faced by social media companies in policing their platforms and the potential for government influence over their content moderation policies.

### **No. 16: Insults directed to and from Donald Trump and other Republicans**

In 2020, it was reported that Twitter had been censoring tweets from Donald Trump and other Republicans, citing concerns about the spread of hate speech and harassment. The decision sparked a debate about the limits of free speech on social media and the responsibilities of social media companies in policing their platforms.

Some argued that Twitter had overstepped its bounds by censoring Trump's tweets, while others argued that it had failed to take adequate action to prevent the spread of hate speech and harassment.

### **No. 17: Global Engagement Center**

In 2018, it was reported that the U.S. Department of State had established a Global Engagement Center aimed at countering Russian propaganda and disinformation. The center was reportedly working with social media companies, including Twitter, to develop strategies for countering Russian propaganda.

The revelation sparked a debate about the role of government in social media content moderation and the potential for overreach. Some argued that the Global Engagement Center was necessary to counter Russian propaganda, while others argued that it represented a threat to free speech and the independence of social media companies.

### **No. 19: The Virality Project**

In 2020, it was reported that the Stanford History Education Group had launched a project called the Virality Project, aimed at tracking and analyzing the spread of misinformation on social media. The project used machine learning algorithms to identify and flag suspicious content, but it was widely criticized for its methodology and its potential for bias.

The controversy highlighted the challenges faced by social media companies in policing their platforms and the potential for government influence over their content moderation policies.

article:
2023 FIVB Men's Volleyball Nations League

The 2023 FIVB Men's Volleyball Nations League (VNL) was the 5th edition of the FIVB Volleyball Nations League, a global men's volleyball competition organized by the Fédération Internationale de Volleyball (FIVB). The tournament took place from May 16 to June 18, 2023.

Qualification

The qualification process for the 2023 VNL was similar to the previous editions, with the FIVB ranking teams based on their performance in the 2022 VNL and other international competitions. The top 16 teams in the FIVB ranking qualified directly for the VNL, while the remaining teams played in a qualification tournament to secure the last two spots.

Format

The 2023 VNL featured a preliminary round and a final round. The preliminary round consisted of six pools of four teams each, with each team playing the other teams in their pool once. The top two teams from each pool qualified for the final round.

### Preliminary round

* Each pool played a round-robin format, with each team playing the other teams in their pool once.
* The top two teams from each pool qualified for the final round.

### Final round

* The 12 teams that qualified for the final round were divided into two groups of six teams each.
* Each team played the other teams in their group once, with the top two teams from each group qualifying for the quarterfinals.

Pool standing procedure

The pool standing procedure was as follows:

* Each team earned points based on their performance in each match. A win earned 3 points, a draw earned 2 points, and a loss earned 1 point.
* The teams were ranked based on their total points earned in the preliminary round.

**2021-22 European Windstorm Season**

The 2021-22 European windstorm season was a period of significant storm activity across Europe, with numerous intense low-pressure systems bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas to various regions. This article provides an overview of the background and naming conventions used by European meteorological services, a summary of the season, and a detailed list of notable storms.

**Background and Naming**

The naming of European windstorms is typically coordinated by national meteorological services and follows a specific convention. There are six regional groups, each responsible for naming storms within their designated area:

### Western Group (United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands)

The Western Group includes the United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands. This region is prone to strong winds and stormy weather due to its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean. Storms in this area are often named from a list of pre-determined names, which are selected by the Met Office (UK), Met Éireann (Ireland), and the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI).

### South-western Group (France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg)

The South-western Group covers France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg. This region experiences a mix of Mediterranean and Atlantic influences, leading to a varied climate with frequent storm activity. The storms in this area are named by Météo-France (France), the Spanish State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA), and the Royal Meteorological Institute of Belgium.

### Eastern Mediterranean Group (Greece, Israel, and Cyprus)

The Eastern Mediterranean Group includes Greece, Israel, and Cyprus. This region is characterized by a Mediterranean climate with hot summers and mild winters. Storms in this area are named by the National Observatory of Athens (Greece), the Israel Meteorological Service, and the Cyprus Department of Meteorology.

### Central Mediterranean Group (Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta)

The Central Mediterranean Group covers Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta. This region experiences a Mediterranean climate with a mix of warm and humid air from the Mediterranean Sea. The storms in this area are named by the Italian National Institute of Statistics (ISTAT), the Slovenian Environment Agency, the Croatian Meteorological and Hydrological Service, the Montenegrin Hydrometeorological Institute, the Republic of North Macedonia's Hydrometeorological Service, and the Malta Meteorological Office.

### Northern Group (Iceland, Denmark, Norway, Finland, and Sweden)

The Northern Group includes Iceland, Denmark, Norway, Finland, and Sweden. This region is characterized by a cold and temperate climate with frequent storm activity. The storms in this area are named by the Icelandic Met Office, the Danish Meteorological Institute, the Norwegian Meteorological Institute, the Finnish Meteorological Institute, and the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute.

**Season Summary**

The 2021-22 European windstorm season was marked by a high number of intense low-pressure systems, with many storms causing significant disruptions across various regions. The season was characterized by a combination of factors, including a persistent high-pressure system over the Atlantic Ocean and a warming Arctic, which led to an increased risk of stormy weather.

The 2021-22 European windstorm season had a significant impact on various regions across Europe. The storms caused widespread disruptions, power outages, and economic losses. **2022 US Open (tennis)**

The 2022 US Open was the 142nd edition of the US Open tennis tournament, held from August 29 to September 11, 2022, at the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, New York City. It was a Grand Slam tournament, one of the four most prestigious tournaments in the world of tennis, and was organized by the United States Tennis Association (USTA).

**Tournament**

The 2022 US Open was the 11th Grand Slam tournament of the year, following the Australian Open and the French Open. The tournament featured a total of 256 players competing in the singles events, 128 players in the doubles events, and 16 players in the wheelchair events. The tournament was played on hard courts, with the main show court being the Arthur Ashe Stadium.

**Broadcast**

The 2022 US Open was broadcast in over 200 countries and territories around the world, with the main broadcast partners being ESPN, CBS, and the Tennis Channel in the United States. The tournament was also streamed live on various online platforms, including ESPN+, the US Open app, and the Tennis Channel app. The broadcast schedule included all matches from the first round to the final, with coverage of the key matches and events throughout the tournament.

**Singles players**

The 2022 US Open singles events featured a total of 128 players competing in each event, with the top seeds in each event being:

* Men's singles: Novak Djokovic (1), Daniil Medvedev (2), Stefanos Tsitsipas (3), and Alexander Zverev (4)

The men's doubles event was won by Rajeev Ram and Joe Salisbury, who defeated Wesley Koolhof and Neal Skupski in the final with a score of 7-6(7-4), 7-5. This was Ram's third US Open title and his first with Salisbury.

The women's doubles event was won by Sabrina Santamaria and Caty McNally, who defeated Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula in the final with a score of 6-4, 6-2. This was Santamaria's first US Open title and her first with McNally.

### Mixed doubles

The mixed doubles event was won by Mallory Bryan and Édouard Roger-Vasselin, who defeated Katarzyna Piter and Michael Venus in the final with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This was Bryan's first US Open title and her first with Roger-Vasselin.

The wheelchair quad doubles event was won by Dylan Alcott and Heath Davidson, who defeated Niels Vink and Sam Schröder in the final with a score of 6-3, 6-1. This was Alcott's third Grand Slam wheelchair quad doubles title.

The boys' singles event was won by Gabriel Debru, who defeated Gabriel Diallo in the final with a score of 6-4, 5-7, 6-2. This was Debru's first Grand Slam boys' singles title.

**Bullet Train (film)**

**Introduction**
Bullet Train is a 2022 American action comedy film directed by David Leitch and written by Zak Olkewicz. The film is an adaptation of the Japanese novel "Maria Beetle" by Kōtarō Isaka, and it features an ensemble cast, including Brad Pitt, Joey King, Aaron Taylor-Johnson, and Sandra Bullock. The film follows a group of assassins who are brought together on a bullet train traveling from Tokyo to Morioka, Japan, where they must navigate their respective missions while dealing with the complications that arise from their interactions with each other.

**Plot**
The film begins with a group of assassins, each with their own unique skills and motivations, who are brought together on the bullet train. The main protagonist, Ladybug (played by Brad Pitt), is a novice assassin who is struggling to find his place in the world. He is joined by a group of seasoned assassins, including Lemon (played by Sandra Bullock), Hornet (played by Zazie Beetz), and Tangerine (played by Brian Tyree Henry).

As the train travels through the Japanese countryside, the assassins are each tasked with completing their respective missions. However, things become complicated when they realize that they are all after the same target, a wealthy businessman named Go (played by Hiroyuki Sanada). The assassins must navigate their way through the train, avoiding each other and the train's security systems, while also dealing with the complications that arise from their interactions with each other.

As the body count rises and the stakes grow higher, Ladybug and the other assassins must use all of their skills and cunning to survive and complete their missions. Along the way, Ladybug must confront his own demons and learn to trust himself and others in order to succeed.

**Cast**
The film features an ensemble cast, including:

* Brad Pitt as Ladybug
* Joey King as Prince
* Aaron Taylor-Johnson as Taro Yashida
* Sandra Bullock as Lemon
* Zazie Beetz as Hornet
* Brian Tyree Henry as Tangerine
* Hiroyuki Sanada as Go
* Michael Shannon as The Driver
* Bad Bunny as Yuichi Kimura
* Awkwafina as Kimura's Mother

**Production**
### Development and Casting
The film was first announced in 2020, with David Leitch set to direct and Zak Olkewicz set to write the screenplay. The project was based on the Japanese novel "Maria Beetle" by Kōtarō Isaka, and it was intended to be a Western adaptation of the book. The film's cast was announced in 2021, with Brad Pitt, Joey King, and Aaron Taylor-Johnson joining the project.

### Filming
Filming for the film took place in Japan in the summer of 2021. The production team used a combination of real trains and studio sets to create the film's bullet train sequences. The film's action scenes were choreographed by the film's stunt team, which included experienced stunt performers from around the world.

**Music**
The film's score was composed by Dominic Lewis, who is known for his work on a variety of film and television projects. The film's soundtrack also features a number of popular songs, including a track by the Japanese rock band, RADWIMPS.

**Release**
The film was released in the United States on August 5, 2022, and it was distributed by Sony Pictures. The film was released in a number of formats, including IMAX and Dolby Cinema.

**Reception**
### Box Office
The film was a commercial success, grossing over $230 million worldwide. The film was a top-ten box office performer in a number of countries, including the United States, China, and Japan.

### Critical Response
The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising its action sequences, cast, and direction. However, some critics felt that the film's plot was predictable and that the characters were underdeveloped.

### Representation of Race in Casting
The film has been criticized for its lack of diversity in casting, with many of the lead roles being played by white actors. However, the film's cast also includes a number of actors from different racial and ethnic backgrounds, including Sandra Bullock, who plays the role of Lemon, a African American assassin.

### Accolades
The film has received a number of awards and nominations, including several Teen Choice Awards and a Saturn Award nomination for Best Action/Adventure Film.

Turning Red

Turning Red is a 2022 American computer-animated coming-of-age comedy film produced by Pixar Animation Studios and released by Walt Disney Pictures. The film follows the story of a 13-year-old girl named Meilin "Mei" Lee, who experiences a strange transformation that turns her into a giant red panda whenever she becomes too excited or stressed.

Plot
--------

The film revolves around Mei, a Chinese-Canadian teenager who is struggling to balance her family and social life. She is constantly worried about her mother's expectations, her relationships with her friends, and her own identity. One day, Mei's life is turned upside down when she discovers that she has the ability to turn into a giant red panda whenever she becomes too excited or stressed. This transformation is a manifestation of her emotions and becomes a recurring theme throughout the film.

As Mei navigates her new reality, she must learn to control her emotions and find ways to manage her stress and anxiety. Along the way, she meets a group of friends who help her to understand and cope with her transformation. The film explores themes of identity, self-acceptance, and the importance of finding one's own way in life.

Turning Red was first announced in 2018, with Domee Shi being announced as the director and co-writer of the film. Ken Jeong and Paul Sun-Hyung Lee play Mei's father Jin and grandfather Ben, respectively. The film also features Hye Young Park as Miriam, a friend of Mei's, and Tramell Tillman as Darryl, a teenager who becomes infatuated with Mei.

Design

The film is set in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, and takes place in the early 2000s. The story is heavily influenced by Mei's Chinese-Canadian heritage, with many cultural references and traditions woven throughout the narrative.

Inspirations
-------------

The film's creator, Domee Shi, has cited several inspirations for Turning Red, including her own experiences as a Chinese-Canadian teenager and her love of anime and manga. The film's animation style is heavily influenced by traditional Chinese art and architecture, with vibrant colors and intricate details.

Music
--------

The film's soundtrack features a mix of contemporary and classic Chinese music, with songs by artists such as Cui Jian and Faye Wong. The score was composed by Ludwig Göransson, who is known for his work on films such as Black Panther and Creed.

Marketing

Promotion

Turning Red was heavily promoted by Disney and Pixar, with a series of trailers and TV spots released in the months leading up to its release. The film's marketing campaign focused on the film's unique animation style and its themes of identity and self-acceptance.

Tie-in media

A range of merchandise was released to tie in with the film, including toys, clothing, and accessories. The film's soundtrack was also released on CD and digital platforms.

Release

------------------------

Turning Red was released in theaters on March 11, 2022, and was also available to stream on Disney+. The film was released in a range of formats, including 2D and 3D, and was available in several languages, including English, Spanish, and Mandarin.

Home media
------------

Turning Red was released on Blu-ray and DVD on June 14, 2022, and was available for digital purchase and rent on platforms such as iTunes and Amazon Video.

Censorship

The film was not subject to any major censorship, although some minor cuts were made in certain countries to conform to local regulations. In China, the film was released with a rating of 12+, which is the highest rating given to a film in the country.

Turning Red was a commercial success, grossing over $220 million worldwide. The film performed well in several countries, including the United States, China, and Japan.

Viewership
------------

The film was watched by over 100 million viewers worldwide, making it one of the most-watched films of the year.

Critical response
----------------

Turning Red received widespread critical acclaim, with praise for its animation, storytelling, and themes. The film holds a 95% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.5/10.

Accolades

Turning Red won several awards, including the Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film and the BAFTA Award for Best Animated Film. The film was also nominated for several other awards, including the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature Film.

Future

A sequel to Turning Red is in development, with Domee Shi returning as director and co-writer. The film is expected to be released in the late 2020s.
